facts.text: Krishtarao died in 1890 leaving surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai and a son Dattatraya.

anchor.surface_text: Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving him surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai and a son Dattatraya.

facts.text: Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath.

anchor.surface_text: Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving him surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath.

facts.text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya in 1913.

anchor.surface_text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914.

facts.text: Jagannath died in 1914.

anchor.surface_text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914.

facts.text: Gangabai survived both her son and grandson.

anchor.surface_text: After an interval of about 30 years since his death, it is alleged that Gangabai who survived both her son,

facts.text: Plaintiff Dattatraya Gurunath claims he was adopted in 1943 by Gangabai.

anchor.surface_text: Dattatraya Gurunath, the plaintiff, claims that he was adopted in 1943 by Gangabai, widow of Krishtarao.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit on 15th March 1944 in forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: On the 15th of March, 1944 the appellant instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises in forma pauperis

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed possession of adoptive father's properties comprised in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that he was the adopted son of Krishtarao and adopted to him by Gangabai, his junior widow, and as such was entitled to the possession of his adoptive fathers properties

facts.text: Defendants disputed plaintiff's adoption on ground that Gangabai's power extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving widow and son.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants who are the sons and grandsons of the first cousin of Krishtarao disputed the plaintiffs adoption on the ground that Gangabais power to adopt was extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913, leaving behind him a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath

facts.text: Gangabai supported plaintiff's claim and asserted Radhabai consented to adoption.

anchor.surface_text: Gangabai in her written statement supported the plaintiffs claim and asserted that the senior widow Radhabai had given consent to her adopting the plaintiff.

facts.text: Trial judge upheld defendants' contention and dismissed plaintiff's suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial judge upheld the defendants contention and dismissed the plaintiffs suit.

facts.text: Trial court upheld factum of plaintiff's adoption.

anchor.surface_text: The factum of the plaintiffs adoption was however upheld,

facts.text: Trial court held Radhabai did not give consent to adoption.

anchor.surface_text: and it was further held that Radhabai did not give her consent to the adoption.

facts.text: High Court affirmed trial court decision on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal this decision was affirmed by the High Court

facts.text: High Court held Gangabai's power to adopt ended when her son died leaving son and widow.

anchor.surface_text: and it was held that Gangabais power to adopt came to an end at the time when her son died leaving a son and a widow to continue the family line.

facts.text: High Court gave no finding on Radhabai's consent.

anchor.surface_text: No finding was given on the question whether Radhabai had given her consent to the adoption.

facts.text: Appeal before Supreme Court by special leave in forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the High Court this appeal in forma pauperis is now before us by special leave.

facts.text: Defendants are sons and grandsons of first cousin of Krishtarao.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants who are the sons and grandsons of the first cousin of Krishtarao

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed declaration on compensation money for land acquired by Hubli Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: He also claimed a declaration regarding the amount of compensation money payable to the plaintiffs family for the land acquired by Hubli Municipality.

facts.text: Supreme Court held widow's power to adopt comes to an end by interposition of grandson or son's widow competent to continue the line.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we are unable to depart from the rule that a widows power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to continue the line by adoption.

Against the decision of the High Court this appeal in forma pauperis is now before us by special leave.

whether a widow can exercise a power of adoption conferred on her or possessed by her at any time during her life irrespective of any devolution of property or changes in the family or other circumstances

concepts.interpretation: Power possessed by widow under Hindu law to adopt for continuing husband's line, subject to judicial limitations.

concepts.interpretation: Once the duty to continue the line passes to grandson or son's widow, the grandmother's power extinguishes permanently and cannot revive.

arguments.claim: Hindu Shastric Law itself sets no limit to the exercise of the widow's power of adoption once she has acquired that power or is possessed of it, and the power can be exercised by her during her life-time when necessity arises for continuing the line of her husband.

arguments.claim: Though Hindu Shastric Law sets no limit, it has long been judicially recognised that the power is not unlimited and comes to an end when another heir comes on the scene and passes the duty of continuing the line.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it was argued that though Hindu Shastric Law itself sets no limit to the exercise of the power, yet it has long been judicially recognised that the power is not an unlimited and absolute one, and that it comes to an end when another heir has come on the scene and he has passed on to another the duty of continuing the line.

arguments.claim: In absence of clear Shastric text, courts decide on principles of justice, equity and good conscience.

anchor.surface_text: It is well known that in the absence of any clear Shastric text the courts have authority to decide cases on principles of justice, equity and good conscience

arguments.claim: The rule that power ends by interposition has become part of Hindu law for three quarters of a century; too late to depart.

anchor.surface_text: The result of these series of decisions is, that now for about three quarters of a century the rule that the power of a widow to adopt comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to adopt has become a part of Hindu Law

arguments.claim: A widow's power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the son's widow competent to continue the line by adoption.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we are unable to depart from the rule that a widows power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to continue the line by adoption.

holdings.text: we are unable to depart from the rule that a widows power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to continue the line by adoption.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Extensive review of Privy Council decisions from Chundrabullee to Amarendra confirms the rule as integral to Hindu law; spiritual duty passes permanently; no Shastric text mandates unlimited power; equity supports limits.

holdings.text: the rule that the power of a widow to adopt comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to adopt has become a part of Hindu Law
holdings.reasoning_summary: Series of decisions over 75 years establishes rule as settled Hindu law despite no direct Shastric text; courts fill gaps with justice, equity, good conscience.

holdings.text: in the absence of any clear Shastric text the courts have authority to decide cases on principles of justice, equity and good conscience
holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial power to interpret Hindu law absent texts justifies limits on adoption power.

holdings.text: it is too late in the day to say that there are no limitations of any kind on the widows power to adopt excepting those that limit the power of her husband to adopt
holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical precedents and lack of substantial challenge affirm additional judicial limits beyond husband's power constraints.

holdings.text: the ratio of the decision in Bapuji v. Gangaram 1941 I.L.R. Nagpur 178 was erroneous
holdings.reasoning_summary: Misapprehends Amarendra; duty ends permanently upon interposition, no revival even after deaths.

holdings.text: The three propositions that the Privy Council laid down in Amarendras case therefore cannot be questioned
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms: (1) interposition ends power; (2) independent of property devolution; (3) not by son's ceremonial competence alone.

holdings.text: where the duty of providing for the continuance of the line for spiritual purposes which was upon the father and was laid by him conditionally upon the mother, has been assumed by the son and by him passed on to the grandson or to the sons widow, the mothers power is gone
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explains basis in Amarendra: permanent transfer of spiritual duty upon interposition.
